Situation1: They support a mentee facing a high-stakes project that could determine their future career trajectory.
Situation2: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Story: I stood behind the register, my mentee’s anxious text lighting up my phone just as a customer slammed a bag of groceries onto the counter. “You overcharged me!” she snapped, her voice rising above the holiday chaos. I forced a smile, recalling the training: patience, empathy, never let frustration show. But my mind was with my mentee, who was about to present their first big project—one that could make or break their career. They needed my encouragement, my advice, right now. I could almost hear their nervous voice, see their trembling hands. Yet here I was, expected to be the model of calm, to resolve this customer’s anger with grace. My heart pounded as I juggled the demands: be the steady mentor, be the perfect cashier. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
